description: From Middle English ote, from Old English āte, from Proto-Germanic *aitǭ (“swelling; gland; nodule”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁eyd- (“to swell”). See English atter.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Widely cultivated cereal grass, typically Avena sativa.
examples: The oat stalks made good straw.
The main forms of oat are meal and bran.
World trade in oat is increasing.

entries.meaning: (countable) Any of the numerous species, varieties, or cultivars of any of several similar grain plants in genus Avena.
examples: The wild red oat is thought to be the ancestor of modern food oats.

entries.meaning: (usually as plural) The seeds of the oat, a grain, harvested as a food crop.
A simple musical pipe made of oat-straw.
The tiniest amount; a whit or jot.
examples: Few of them care an oat for the niceties of the arrow sport, but for the young lords that may be on a hunt!
